titles.title: Commending the Republic of Croatia for the conduct of its parliamentary and presidential elections.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on International Relations.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.

action.text: Mr. Gilman moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Con. Res. 251.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

calendar.text: Committee on Foreign Relations. Ordered to be reported with an amendment favorably.

action.text: Committee on Foreign Relations. Reported by Senator Helms with an amendment in the nature of a substitute and with an amended preamble. Without written report.

calendar.text: Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 593.

vote.text: Resolution agreed to in Senate with an amendment and an amended preamble by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

term.name: Civil rights and liberties, minority issues

bill.summary: 6/23/2000--Passed Senate amended. Congratulates the people of the Republic of Croatia on successful parliamentary and presidential elections and commends the outgoing Government of Croatia for the democratic standards with which it managed the elections.Expresses support for Croatia's commitment to western democratic standards and to the new Government fully implementing democratic reforms.Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States: (1) should support the efforts of the new Government of Croatia to increase its work on refugee return, privatization reform, media reform, and further cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for Former Yugoslavia; and (2) continues to promote Croatian-American economic, political, and military relations and recognizes Croatia as a loyal partner in south central Europe.
